stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on Course 11, 'Oily Boily Bay,' focusing on level layout and implementing new platforming mechanics. He brainstormed, modeled, and programmed wind turbines, overcoming a significant 'gimbal lock' technical issue. Throughout the stream, he discussed his design philosophies, critiqued other games, and reacted to his YouTube channel's analytics.

development_findings.summary: The project is significantly advanced, with the current level being the 11th of 15 planned courses.
development_findings.quote: It is course 11 out of 15. So 11 means we are already pretty far.

development_findings.summary: The game is currently 42.8MB, staying within the 64MB ROM size limitation.
development_findings.quote: We're in course 11 and we are 42.8 megabytes in size.

development_findings.summary: Kaze critiques Sonic Mania's design, specifically its reliance on memorization and unreactable hazards, using it as an anti-pattern for his own level design.
development_findings.quote: Sonic will make you make jumps that require 90 millisecond reaction time... You have to go slow if you want to play Sonic without getting hit and that's literally just fucking boring.

development_findings.summary: Kaze solved a gimbal lock issue, where he couldn't rotate a turbine model correctly in-engine, by creating a new, pre-rotated 3D model in Blender.
development_findings.quote: We have to take the model. We have to rotate it 90 degrees in the 3D model. This is the only way to do it.

development_findings.summary: While open to puzzle elements, Kaze wants to ensure they remain simple and do not create significant roadblocks for the player.
development_findings.quote: I think you can design some fun puzzles around having some turbines on and off and hitting buttons to invert a state. ... As long as we make the puzzles like baby easy I'm up for that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a desire to create a very difficult final level but is hesitant, weighing the challenge against potential player frustration.
development_findings.quote: I would really like to have a fuck and fuck... I know boss level. But like I'm a little horrid saw.

development_findings.summary: Kaze rejects the idea of adding consumable items (like bubbles to prevent falling) because he believes it promotes a tedious gameplay loop of grinding and resetting rather than skillful play.
development_findings.quote: The problem I have with that is that it kind of encourages a very lame play style... It adds a lot of misery to the game and takes away the tension.

development_findings.summary: Kaze notes that the design process for 'Oily Boily Bay' is more improvisational and modular than his typical level creation workflow.
development_findings.quote: This level is a bit improvised compared to my normal levels. We're kind of making a lot of shit up on the fly.

development_findings.summary: Lilaa, another contributor, gave feedback that led to a change in the game's camera system.
Kaze showcased Course 1 running with a near-infinite draw distance, achieving what he describes as a 'GameCube game' look, though it suffers from FPS drops to ~20 in worst-case scenarios.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a personal philosophy of frugality.
context_findings.quote: I never buy anything. I hate buying stuff. I like having money.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is frustrated that his low-effort April Fool's video is more popular than his serious, high-effort technical and creative videos, leading him to question audience priorities on YouTube.
context_findings.quote: This revolutionizing N64 programming, less than fucking Grass April Fool's video. ... No one gives a shit about anything.

context_findings.summary: Kaze theorizes that the YouTube algorithm favors long, less-engaging content that can be consumed passively, influencing his thoughts on video creation.
context_findings.quote: I have the theory that right now Youtube is in the background noise matter. You're not supposed to make engaging videos. You're supposed to make videos that can be listened to while they're in the background.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions his bike was stolen, putting him in a bad mood at the start of the stream.
Kaze is preparing a talk for a tech conference in August about reverse engineering and hacking N64 games.
Kaze was diagnosed with tennis elbow from lifting weights but is skeptical of the doctor's treatment plan, preferring to treat it himself.

biobak.summary: Biobak, present in the chat, offers to recreate a texture he made previously when Kaze can't find the original file, showing a fluid and collaborative workflow.
biobak.quote: Right, so I looked into that file back. I don't know if I have the original file for it anymore... It might just be faster to recreate it.

key_stories.title: The Gimbal Lock Turbine
key_stories.summary: Kaze encountered a frustrating 'gimbal lock' problem when trying to create a horizontal variant of a wind turbine. After failed attempts to rotate it in-engine, he solved it by creating an entirely new, pre-rotated 3D model, highlighting a technical workaround required by the engine's limitations.
key_stories.challenge: A horizontal version of the wind turbine was needed for a platforming section, but rotating the existing vertical model in the game engine resulted in incorrect orientation due to gimbal lock.
key_stories.process: Kaze first attempted to rotate the model in-game using its pitch, roll, and yaw properties. After realizing all three axes were producing the same, incorrect rotation, he expressed frustration and recalled solving a similar problem before. He concluded the only solution was to modify the asset itself outside the game engine.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze created a new, separate 3D model that was pre-rotated 90 degrees in Blender. This new asset worked correctly in the engine for horizontal placement, successfully bypassing the gimbal lock issue.
key_stories.key_quote: Fucking gimbal lock. I hate this. How did I do this with the windmill? How did I manage to do it before? Oh, I know how I did it before.

key_stories.title: Critique of Sonic Mania's Design
key_stories.summary: Kaze used Sonic Mania as a case study for what he considers bad game design. He argued its reliance on unreactable, off-screen hazards is unfair and outdated, and he proved his point by finding an example in a random gameplay video, thus cementing his own design philosophy of fairness.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed to decide on a design philosophy for hazards and platforming challenges in the new level.
key_stories.process: While brainstorming, Kaze brought up Sonic Mania as a negative example. He argued its design was outdated and unfair for modern players who don't memorize levels. To prove his point, he pulled up a random gameplay video on stream and immediately found an example of an unavoidable hazard, reinforcing his design choice.
key_stories.outcome: He solidified his commitment to fair, reactable challenges and rejected the 'gotcha' design style, deciding to create mechanics like timed turbines that test skill rather than rote memorization.
key_stories.key_quote: I didn't even look very long at the video. It literally took me five seconds to find this clip. That's why Sonic mania is trash. I have proven my point.

key_stories.title: The April Fool's Video Dilemma
key_stories.summary: Kaze expressed frustration after noticing his April Fool's meme video vastly outperformed his serious, high-effort development videos. This led to a reflection on YouTube's algorithm and audience, and a conflicted decision to continue the popular meme format annually despite his feelings.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze is grappling with the disconnect between the content he is passionate about creating and the content that performs well on YouTube.
key_stories.process: Kaze reviewed his YouTube analytics on stream, comparing the high view count of his simple 'Touching Grass' April Fool's video to the lower counts on his complex programming and level design videos. He expressed that he found this disparity insulting and depressing.
key_stories.outcome: He decides to make the April Fool's video an annual tradition, embracing its popularity, but remains audibly frustrated by the disparity in viewership. This leads him to theorize that YouTube's 'meta' favors passive, 'background noise' content over focused, technical showcases.
key_stories.key_quote: You know what's depressing? Even though that video was an April Fool's joke, it did better than most of my normal videos.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned he will be a speaker at a tech conference in August, where he will talk about reverse engineering and hacking N64 games.

open_questions.context: Kaze wants to make a very difficult final level but is concerned about frustrating casual players, mentioning the total star count might serve as a buffer for players who don't want to complete it.
questions: What is your definition of a 'good' difficult final level versus a 'bad' or 'frustrating' one?
How does the existence of optional, easier stars elsewhere in the game give you the freedom to be more punishing in the final level?

open_questions.topic: Collaboration and Feedback Loop with Lilaa
open_questions.context: Kaze explicitly states that he changed the camera because contributor Lilaa complained about it, and he also attempted to fix an art asset (mouse cutouts) based on her live feedback.
questions: Can you walk me through the typical feedback process with Lilaa? How does she communicate issues she finds?
What was the specific problem with the camera that she identified?
How much influence does this kind of ad-hoc feedback from team members have on the final product?

open_questions.context: Kaze is strongly against adding too many options, particularly cosmetic ones or those that trivialize gameplay, like buying bubbles to prevent falling.
questions: You've said you prefer fewer, more satisfactory options. Where do you draw the line between a meaningful choice (like accessibility) and a trivial one?
What's the worst-case scenario you imagine if you gave in to all the requests for minor options?
How do you balance your design integrity with player desire for customization?
